Participants.evidence: 336 eligible participants who self-identified as black and 50 years or older with chronic and frequent knee pain, a Western Ontario McMaster Universities Osteoarthritis Index score of at least 39, and radiographic evidence of OA of the knee were recruited from December 1, 2010, to May 31, 2014, at 3 medical centers.

Intervention.evidence: Access to a decision aid for OA of the knee, a 40-minute video that describes the risks and benefits of TKR surgery.

Objective.evidence: To assess whether a decision aid improves access to total knee replacement (TKR) surgery for black patients with OA of the knee.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Receipt of TKR surgery within 12 months and/or a recommendation for TKR surgery from an orthopedic surgeon within 6 months after the intervention.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Among 336 patients (101 men [30.1%]; 235 women [69.9%]; mean [SD] age, 59.1 [7.2] years) randomized to the intervention or control group

Number_Analysed.evidence: Data were analyzed on a per-protocol and intention-to-treat (ITT) basis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: adjusted ORs were 2.10 (95%CI, 1.04–4.27) for the ITT analysis and 2.39 (95%CI, 1.12–5.10) for the per-protocol analysis
